Good morning everyone! How are you doing today? 
Today, we will talk all about your business plan. Up to this point, you thought everything through and you are starting to actually start your businesses! The business plan is a chance for you to put all of the most important information in one place.

BUSINESS PLAN
20-30 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What do you guys know about business plans? Why is it useful to have one?
 Show stakeholders that you have a clear strategy and plan for long-term success.

Ask: What are the different parts of a business plan? What are the things that you should show to prove that you have the best idea out there?
Have the entrepreneurs explain what they think is most important.
Try to write out the flow of an entire business plan based on what they say.
After, go through the next slides to touch on the points they missed or go deeper on the important elements. 

Recap: A business plan is just like your pitch in the sense that it tells a story about why your business is a good bet. After pitching or getting some interest from an investor/granting organization, they might ask you for more information. Depending on the person, they might ask for a meeting or for a copy of your business plan. This business plan is your chance to show your professionalism and to dive into the details of your action plan. Many people think of a business plan as a long boring document that nobody looks at (which some people still do), but the business plan has evolved over time. It is detailed, but avoids unnecessary content. The main thing to show is where your business has been, where it is going, and how you plan on getting there.
Classical: 
Long 50 page documents that nobody reads. 
To many unnecessary details. 
Quantity over quality. 
Black and white, text heavy, boring.
Modern: 
There has been a shift to either pitch decks or short comprehensive plans. 
These business plans are action oriented and interesting for the reader. 
Quality over quantity.
Represents your brand, highly visual, interesting.

2 minutes: Transition
All of those points are correct, what we will do now is cover some of the key elements that should be included in a business plan. None of this is new, throughout the incubator you have already done this! Now it is about putting it together on one clean document! We will go over the points briefly, then we will spend the rest of the session working on them. You can follow along on your business plan template we sent you.

3

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Where you are now
How you plan on getting there
Where you want to be
3-5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The executive summary is the first thing in a business plan, but the very last thing you write. After you write out the whole business plan, you pull out the most important information and create a one page teaser document. This will highlight all of the important points you want to make in a brief overview.  It explains:
Where you are now: Why do you do what you do? Why are you here? What is the problem you have identified and what is the solution (your product/service)?
Where you want to be: What is the end result you are looking to achieve? What is the long-term impact and growth potential of your business?
How you plan on getting there: How are you planning to accomplish this? How do you know this will work?

If it wasn’t covered in the earlier brainstorm, ask: Why is this section really important to have?
You can send this out to people who might be interested in your business. If they are interested, they might ask for more information
You should be able to sum up the key elements of your business plan in one page! Where are you now, where do you want to go, and how will you get there?
It will highlight the most important things. People don’t have to read the whole thing if they don’t want to. 



4

BUSINESS DESCRIPTION
3-5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The next section is your business description. This is a really high level explanation of what you do. Be clear and simple. Don’t try to be fancy and use complicated explanations or jargon. You want people to really understand who you are and why you are here. 
Ask: When describing your business, which points should you include?
Description: Tell us about your business. Who are you, why are you here, and what do you do (think challenge-solution)? 
Make sure the way you talk about your business is consistent on your pitch, business plan, website, and social media. 
If you talk about your business one way in the executive summary, talk about it the same way in your business description!
Mission Statement, Vision, values, and Goals: What do you want to accomplish through the existence of your business (usually not financial accomplishments)?
Remember, write what works. If you think it is repetitive and not effective to write all of these, then don’t! You choose what will tell the best story for your business (where you have been, where you are going, how you will get there)
Products and services:  What are you offering, and what is its unique value? Be clear and obvious here.  
Ask: When describing your products, what should you include? 
Potential answers:
The name of your products/services (write all revenue streams)
Pricing mechanism
Competitive advantage of each product/service
Any patents? Copyrights?
Photos/screenshots (professional-looking ones!)

5

MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATION
 3-5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The next section is your business management and organization. How will your business operate? What are key operational or organizational elements of your business that will be key to its success? 
Ask: When thinking about your management and organization, which points should you include?
Allow entrepreneurs to share their thoughts.
Make sure to touch on a few main points:
Your team/organizational structure:
Who is there now? What experience does your team bring to ensure the success of this business?
Who do you plan to have on your team? Consider adding a hiring timeline of key and operational teammates.
What kind of management and structure do you have? Consider including an “organigram” to show how the structure, reporting, and information flows to the different members of your team. 
Do you have a board of advisors?
A solo founder isn’t convincing to investors. They want to see a strong passionate team and a supportive network to reassure them. 
Your legal structure:
Legal requirements. Should you be registered to operate? How will you register?
What is your legal structure? Are you a non profit? Are you a corporation, are you the only owner (sole proprietorship)?
Are there any particular safety or health requirements you should follow?
This section is not necessary for everyone
Key partners:
Do you have any key partners, distributors, manufacturers, etc… that you are working with? 
Explain how your business will operate in coordination with other key players
This is not necessary for everyone
6

Who are your customers?
How big is the market?
Is it growing?
Who else is in the market? 
MARKET ANALYSIS
3-5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The next section is your market analysis. Show evidence based on research. You can take the information from your feasibility study and add it in here. Who are your customers and competitors? How big is the market? 
Ask: If you wanted to prove with evidence that your business was a good bet in this market, what would you want to show?
Potential answers:
 Good feedback from user research and testing
 Market size and future growth potential
 Trends that indicate shifting consumer preferences, operational efficiencies, or regulatory changes that may impact your business
 PESTEL analysis

Next, we have the action plan. What will you do to make this business a success? How can you convince the people around you that this is a sustainable idea and you have thought everything through? Your action plan should clearly explain the steps you will take to turn the idea into a reality (or take your existing business and take it to the next level). Make sure that this is really practical, realistic, and reflects your financial projections.

Go to market strategy
Growth and milestones
Sales and marketing strategy
Locations
Strategy

Ask: What should you show in terms of your financials? What story are you telling here?
Financial history: Show evidence that this idea will work through actual sales!
What sales have you already made?
Can you show any traction?
Key financial or profitability ratios such as CAC, gross margin, and others we have talked about in the past (these can be very meaningful on actual financials)

Financial projections: Show where you expect to be going over the next few years!
Forecasting for 3-5 years
They should be strong numbers, but also realistic and based on facts or your market research.
Does this have potential to make money? 
When will you break even? 
Balance sheet/income statement/cash flow statements are all things that could be included. Remember to put a summary here or 3 year highlights. You can add detailed financials to the appendix if you want.
Key financial or profitability ratios (these won’t be as meaningful if you don’t have a financial history because it is mostly made up)

APPENDICES
1 hour and 25 minutes: Discussion + activity

Finally we have the appendices. You can add anything in here really, just remember to only add things that add value to the story you are telling. Don’t add things for no reason. What do you want to show that will prove that your ideas are great?
Ask: What else might you want to include as an attachment to your business plan? 
Potential answers:
Summary of research
Complicated charts that you don’t want in the body of your document
Screenshots of detailed financials
Competitive benchmarking
SWOT analysis
Pictures of your product
Pictures of people using your product
Etc…

1 hour: Activity
Let the entrepreneurs work on their business plans for the next hour. 
They can use the template we provided, Canva, or anything else. 
Remind them that they can be creative with this and add or remove any sections they would like based on what they think would be valuable information.

20 minutes: Share
Bring them back for the last 20 minutes or so to go around the room and share. 
What was each entrepreneur able to accomplish during this time? 
Did anyone have any trouble? Did anyone have any great successes that they would like to share?

5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The last point we will talk about is the Design and layout of your business plan. Just like a pitch deck, your business plan should be well thought through and designed carefully. You should match themes with your pitch deck, website, application, Facebook page, social media, and more. Remember, you are creating a brand!
Point out that they should feel free to adjust the template we sent out in any they want. We sent a simple word document plan, which is acceptable. 
Substance is more important than design! The design should be there to make it more readable and understandable first. 
Show them alternative layouts (click through the slides):
Tell them to go onto Canva to find some simple, yet creative business plan templates. Simply search “business plan” into the search bar and several options will come up.
Point out that these are just examples and they should find a theme that represents their brand. It should have their logos, photos of their products, and their color and font schemes.

As you now know, a green business may be a
business that sells green products or services,
or which operates according to green princi-
ples. Green businesses therefore contribute
to solving environmental problems and have a
minimal negative impact on the environment.
In order to launch your business, you need to
develop a business plan. The Start Your Busi-
ness (SYB) package has a detailed step-by-
step process for developing a business plan.
The business plan for your green business
needs to be adapted to include key elements
that are critical in starting a green business. In
addition to coming up with a viable green busi-
ness idea (see Chapter 2 for guidance), as you

plan for starting your green business it is im-

ness plan.

your business plan
Writing a green business plan is one of the
most important steps for starting up a green
business. The development of the plan is not
an overnight process and may take several
weeks to complete. The business plan for your
green business should cover all the aspects to
be considered before starting the business.

•

COMPONENT
PURPOSE &
GREEN DIMENSION
Executive summary The executive summary is an outline of your green business idea. In addition to

Your business idea All business plans are based on an idea. In describing your idea, you need to high-

The marketing plan Your marketing plan needs to be based on a solid understanding of the market.
Once you know your market, you then need to develop a marketing plan based
on the 7 “P”s: Product, Price, Place, Promotion, People, Process, and Physical
Evidence. Consider the environmental dimension of these 7 “P”s when developing
the plan (for example, for “Price”, whether you can charge a premium price).
Staff You will need to decide what your business’ staffing needs are based on what tasks
need to be performed. When assessing what staff you need, consider whether any
additional technical skills are needed for your green product/service.
Organization and
management
Like any entrepreneur, you will need to decide on the form of business. A green
business can take one of many forms, including a sole proprietorship, a partner-
ship, or a cooperative, for example. You should weigh the pros and cons of each
before choosing the best form.
You will also need to consider all required taxes and permits and select an appro-
priate insurance policy; make sure to include environmental taxes and environ-
mental permits when doing so.
Buying for your
business
Your business will need to buy before you make or sell your products/services.
When buying for your business, consider how environmentally friendly the materi-
als or equipment you buy are.
Greening your
processes
Greening your processes covers a range of elements, starting from how environ-
mentally friendly your raw materials are to how you get your product to your final
consumers. To ensure the environmental-friendliness of your enterprise, you should
set up an environmental management system (EMS). This system will help you
track and improve your performance in key areas such as procurement, energy and
water consumption, pollution prevention, distribution and waste management.
Costing To be able to set your price and make a financial plan, you will need to calculate
the cost of your products. Keep in mind that you may incur some additional costs
at the outset for green investments relating to equipment, premises or skills, but
also that you will most likely make savings thanks to green practices such a re-
duced consumption of electricity or water, resulting in reduced utility bills.
Financial planning You need to be able to plan and monitor the financial situation of your business
using tools such as the profit plan and a cash flow plan. Like any other business,
your green business needs to perform financially, otherwise you will not be able to
keep it going!
Required start-up
capital
When estimating the required start-up capital, you will need to assess your needs
in terms of capital investment and working capital. Consider the elements required
for your business to be green while estimating this cost, and be realistic when
doing so.
Sources of start-up
capital
The most important types of start-up capital are owner’s equity and loans. Keep in
mind that there are also a number of institutions with special funding opportuni-
ties for green businesses.

Looking at the business plan slides and the Green Business Booklet, I can see several opportunities to integrate environmental resilience elements that would strengthen the curriculum while maintaining its business-first focus. Here's how I would approach enhancing the slides to incorporate green business elements:

## Analysis of Current Slides

The current business plan slides provide a solid framework but miss opportunities to position sustainability as a strategic business advantage. The slides focus on traditional business plan components without acknowledging how green elements can enhance competitiveness, reduce costs, and mitigate risks.

## Recommended Enhancements

### 1. Executive Summary Slide
Add a bullet point suggesting that entrepreneurs highlight any green competitive advantages or sustainability elements that strengthen their value proposition.

Facilitator note: "When summarizing your business, consider mentioning any environmental benefits or efficiency measures that give you a competitive edge or cost advantage."

### 2. Business Description Slide 
Add to the "Mission, Vision, Values" section:
- "Consider how environmental responsibility fits into your values - does it matter to your customers or help differentiate your business?"

Facilitator note: "Green businesses often attract environmentally conscious customers and can command premium pricing. Think about whether highlighting sustainability in your mission/values could strengthen your market position."

### 3. Market Analysis Slide
Add to the "Potential answers" section:
- "Sustainability trends affecting your industry" 
- "Growing consumer demand for environmentally responsible products/services"

Facilitator note: "Environmental trends create both risks and opportunities for businesses. Ask entrepreneurs to consider: Are customers in your market becoming more environmentally conscious? Are competitors using green practices as a selling point? Are there resource constraints that could affect pricing or availability?"

### 4. Action Plan Slide
Add a bullet point:
- "Resource efficiency measures that reduce costs and environmental impact"

Facilitator note: "Discuss how efficiency improvements can create a 'double dividend' - saving money while reducing environmental impact. Ask entrepreneurs to identify specific actions that could achieve both objectives."

### 5. Financial Projections Slide
Add to the "Financial projections" section:
- "Potential cost savings from green measures (energy/water efficiency, waste reduction)"
- "Higher margins from premium 'green' positioning"

Facilitator note: "Remind entrepreneurs that green investments often pay dividends through lower operating costs. For example, energy-efficient equipment might cost more upfront but save money long-term."

### 6. Appendices Slide
Add to "Potential answers":
- "Environmental risk assessment"
- "Resource efficiency analysis"

Facilitator note: "Suggest that entrepreneurs include any analyses showing how their business addresses environmental challenges or improves upon conventional practices."

### 7. New Section: "Integrating Sustainability for Business Advantage"

I recommend adding a new slide after the Organization and Management section:

I like this creative approach to modifying the paper airplane activity! You've integrated resource efficiency concepts in a subtle way that encourages participants to discover these principles through experience rather than direct instruction. Let me refine and expand on your suggestions to create a complete update for the game:

# PAPER AIRPLANE BUSINESS CHALLENGE
## Slide 3: DEVELOP A NEW PRODUCT (Updated version)

```
1 hour: Activity

5 Minutes: Explanation
Entrepreneurs will work in teams to experience a complete business cycle: design, pitch, produce, and sell a product (paper airplanes).

Setup:
- Divide into teams of 3-4 people
- Each team receives limited materials:
  • 3 sheets of standard paper
  • Access to shared resources: markers, scissors, paperclips
- Materials have costs: Each sheet of paper costs $5
- Teams can purchase additional paper during production for $8 per sheet

The Challenge:
- Design a paper airplane that flies well, looks appealing, and uses materials efficiently
- The buyer (trainer) will evaluate planes on:
  1. Flight performance (distance, accuracy)
  2. Design appeal and uniqueness
  3. Resource efficiency (how effectively materials were used)
- These factors will determine the selling price ($2-$20 per plane)

55 Minutes: Activity

10 minutes: Design Phase
- Teams develop their airplane concept and prototype
- Encourage teams to conduct "customer research" by asking what the buyer values
- Teams should consider: How can we design a plane that maximizes quality while minimizing material use?

10 minutes: Pitch & Pricing
- Each team presents their plane and demonstrates flight capabilities
- Trainers evaluate and set a price based on performance, design, and efficiency
- Trainers should reward innovative resource efficiency (e.g., higher price for designs that use minimal material)

15 Minutes: Production Phase
- Teams have 10 minutes to produce multiple planes using their initial materials
- After 5 minutes, announce: "Market demand has increased! A buyer wants 25 planes instead of 15"
- Teams can purchase additional materials if needed, but this cuts into profit margins
- Extend production time by 5 minutes

15 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion
- Calculate profits: (Number of accepted planes × Price) - (Materials cost)
- Rejected planes don't generate revenue, but still count as material cost
- Discuss which teams were most profitable and why

Facilitator note: Watch for teams that develop resource-efficient strategies like making multiple planes from one sheet, minimizing waste, or repurposing scraps. Point these out during discussion as successful business innovations.
```

## New Discussion Points for Slide 4: WHAT HAVE WE LEARNED?

Add these questions to the "Potential questions to ask" section:

```
• How did material constraints affect your design decisions?
• Did any teams find ways to create multiple planes from one sheet? How did this affect your profitability?
• How did teams handle the sudden increase in demand? Did you have to buy more materials or find ways to stretch what you had?
• What strategies did the most profitable teams use to balance quality and resource efficiency?
• How does this exercise relate to real business challenges around resource management?
```

Add these points to the "Possible learning outcomes" section:

```
• Resource efficiency directly impacts profitability - teams that created more value from fewer materials generally earned more
• Smart design thinking upfront can reduce material needs and waste throughout production
• Businesses face tension between quality, speed, and resource use - finding the optimal balance is key
• Adaptability in the face of changing demands often requires rethinking resource allocation
• Sustainability (using resources efficiently) and profitability often go hand-in-hand
```

## Enhancement to Slide 5: DEVELOPMENT PROCESS

Add this bullet under "Research, Design, and Development":

```
• Design for efficiency: How did your initial design choices impact your ability to produce efficiently?
• Some teams may have created designs that were beautiful but used too much material or were too complex to reproduce quickly
• Others may have created simpler designs that could be produced quickly with minimal waste
• This is exactly what businesses must consider - a product's design determines both its resource requirements and production efficiency
```

---

This revised activity creates a genuine business simulation where resource efficiency emerges naturally as a competitive advantage. Rather than explicitly teaching about environmental concepts, it allows participants to discover that efficient resource use is simply good business.

The structure encourages creative problem-solving around resource constraints while maintaining the fun, competitive aspect of the original activity. Importantly, it doesn't require any new materials or complicated setup - just a subtle shift in emphasis and scoring.
